DOC.brief_summary: The purpose of this study is to evaluate self-reported symptoms as a proxy for acute organophosphate poisoning by examining self-reported acute organophosphate poisoning symptoms and PchE activity in response to occupational acute organophosphate exposure among farmers in Nepal.
DOC.brief_title: The Use of Self-reported Symptoms as a Proxy for Acute Organophosphate Poisoning Among Nepali Farmers
DOC.criteria: male minimum age 18 years hand pressured backpack sprayer usage used to spray with moderately to extremely hazardous pesticides according to the World Health Organization's (WHO) Pesticide Hazard Classification usual personal protective equipment use (respirator/mask with particulate filter, face shield, googles, gloves, boots, plastic poncho) unwilling to stay pesticidefree seven days prior to each of the two spray sessions medical conditions interfering with PchE activity (liver disease, acute infection, chronic malnutrition, heart attack, cancer, obstructive jaundice, inflammation caused by various diseases, or use of pyridostigmine drugs)
